awd_titl_txt: Novel Bayesian Inference for Microbial Community Studies Using High-Throughput Sequencing Data
awd_abstract_narration:
The main goal of this project is to develop computationally efficient statistical methods for analyzing large complex metagenomics data and generate a broad impact on future microbial community studies. In particular, by thoroughly combining information across samples and species through a carefully constructed Bayesian hierarchical model, better understanding of influences of environmental and biological factors in microbial communities will be made possible. The PI's findings will be integrated into biology through close collaboration with researchers in Ocean Sciences at University of California Santa Cruz. The PI will disseminate computational tools online via user-friendly software. The developed models, although motivated and constructed to address the problems in microbial community studies, are applicable in general to applications outside the metagenomic field. The project will provide graduate students excellent training opportunities in cutting-edge methods on Bayesian modeling to develop methodological research motivated from practically important and scientifically relevant application areas. 

Microbial communities interact with the environments and host organisms. Scientific investigations of how microbiome interacts with their host, with their environment, and with each other are of great importance to better understanding of their functional roles such as influences on disease risk susceptibility of the host. In microbial community studies, recent breakthroughs in high-throughput sequencing technology allow deep interrogation of microbiome taken from environmental samples and generate statistically new and interesting challenges for analysis of complex sequencing data. The three main objectives are: (1) to develop Bayesian nonparametric (NP) approaches to probabilistically characterize distributions of abundance levels of microbial species; (2) to develop Bayesian regression models to investigate association between abundance of species and covariates; and (3) to develop a Bayesian graphical method to model interaction of species. Instead of treating individual species as separate outcomes, graphs will be used to represent dependencies between species in a probabilistic model and to identify important relationships between species. This will provide more improved inference on the co-occurrence and co-exclusion of the species with honest uncertainty quantification and lead to greater understanding of the microbial interactions. In addition, the PI will develop scalable and efficient computational algorithms to carry out posterior inference for large sequencing data.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of the proposal is to develop novel Bayesian statistical methods that infer microbial communities in environmental samples using 16S rRNA sequencing data.  Motivated by real microbiome studies, we have developed rigorous statistical methods that analyze multivariate count table data with complex structure.  While they can be used for various applications, their main application is microbiome studies to reveal the underlying microbiological mechanisms.  The methods are scientifically relevant, and their inferences are rigorously validated by collaborators in biology. In particular, we have developed statistical methodologies to address the following inferential problems;

Two of the main inferential goals are (a) to accurately estimate microbial abundance distributions in communities and (b) to understand changes in their abundances with respect to their environments and hosts at the species level.  To address those inferential goals, I have worked on the research projects that develop flexible regression models using Bayesian semiparametric and nonparametric approaches and analyze all microbes simultaneously as a community.  Four papers have been published at high-profile journals including JRSS-C and Bayesian Analysis.

Another main inferential goal in the proposal is to provide insights on interactions of microbes in a community.  I have been working on several related projects; the first project is to develop a Bayesian graphical model that infers interaction between microbes. This project provided materials for the Ph.D. thesis of K. Shuler (Chapter 4: Bayesian Graphical Modeling of Microbial Community Composition). For the second project, I took a different approach based on Bayesian factor model, and a resulting covariance estimate provides inference on microbial interaction. A paper on this project has been accepted for publication in AOAS.  Recently, I have been working on an extension of the model for integrating multi-omics datasets to obtain better understanding of the dynamics of microbiomes.

Training and professional developments for students:  Two Ph.D. students, K. Shuler and S. Zhang, in Statistical Sciences at UCSC have been actively involved in the related projects.  K. Shuler worked on three research projects for his Ph.D. dissertation and successfully completed his PhD in Spring 2020, and has been working as a statistician at Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, NM.  His thesis projects have published in Bayesian Analysis and JRSS-C. S. Zhang (a Ph.D. candidate) has been working on research projects related to the award for his Ph.D. dissertation.  He has completed his first thesis project that develops a statistical approach of using continuous kernels with a jointly sparse covariance matrix for multivariate count data. He applied the model for microbiome studies to infer interaction between microbes. He recently started a project on developing a group factor model for joint analysis of multi-omics data.  He successfully advanced to candidacy in Spring 2022. 

In addition, through the collocations with a biologist Dr. Chen at UCLA, I have been working with PhD students, S. Verbanic and Y. Shen in Chemical and Biomolecule Engineering at UCLA.  The collaborative projects provided to the students training opportunities of working with a statistician in developing new analysis methods. The projects have resulted in three journal papers. 

Education:  I have taught STAT 225: multivariate statistical methods in Spring 2018 and Spring 2022, in the Statistics department at UC Santa Cruz. The research projects related to the award deal with statistical methodologies on analysis of high-dimensional count data, specifically for high-dimensional regression and covariance estimation problems. In the class, I included relevant materials of the research projects.  Also, I gave a 2-hour short course on "Bayesian methods of analyzing complex count data with application to microbiome study" in June 2021 at the department of Mathematical Sciences, KAIST, Daejeon, South Korea (Virtual).  I explained statistical challenges in modeling of multivariate count data and presented the research projects with specific examples of microbiome data analysis.

User-Friendly Software: For the statistical models developed in the published journal papers, R packages have been created and made available for public use.  Each computer program was provided with vignette that includes detailed examples for easy use. For example, see https://users.soe.ucsc.edu/~juheelee/ for the models developed in

  1. "A Bayesian Nonparametric Analysis for Zero Inflated Multivariate Count Data with Application to Microbiome Study" by Shuler, et al in JRSS-C (2021)
  2. "Bayesian Sparse Multivariate Regression with Asymmetric Nonlocal Priors for Microbiome Data" by Shuler, et al in Bayesian Analysis (2019)
  3. "A Bayesian Semiparametric Regression Model for Joint Analysis of Microbiome Data" by Lee and Sison-Mangus in Frontiers in Microbiology (2018)

Also, see https://github.com/Zsj950708/ZI-MLN for the model in "Bayesian modeling of Interaction between Features in Sparse Multivariate Count Data with Application to Microbiome Study" by Zhang, et al (in press for AOAS).

Talks at Conferences and Department Seminars: I have given five talks at professional meetings and six department seminars on the related research projects.  I also participated as a discussant in an invited session on Bayesian Microbionomics at JSM 2021.
